TextEquiv.Unicode: ent till his returne, and giveth it to
the Inkeeper. And not being there
withall content, he giveth to his host
an especiall charege of the ficke man:
and also bindeth himelfe for him, say
ing: whatsoever more than this, thou
shalt laye out about thinges necessarie
for his recoverie, thou shalt not loose
one mite: for at my returne, I will
paie thee all againe to the uttermost
farthing. So then he promiseth to re
turne, and therwithall declareth, that
he shall not be quiet, untill he see him
thorowly healed of all his woundes.
Pe have here (dearely beloved) in this
the Lordes Parable, a most godlie
and absolute example of love. For the
Samaritane doth liberallie, and wil
lingly employ his whole seruice upon
his needie neighbours necessitie: Te
therefore owe our selves wholy and
all that we have, to our neighbours
behoofe, which if we bestowe on him,
then doe we fulsill the dueties of love
and civill humanitie.
To this we will yet adde some te
stimonies of the Scripture, that ther
by wee may more fully understande
the verie innermost pith of love, if yet
peradventure anie thing may seeme to
be wanting in that, which hitherto I
have alleadged. Paule therefore wri
ting to the Corinthians, saith: Love
suffereth wrong and is courteous, love
envieth not, love doth not froward
ly, love swelleth not, dealeth not dis
honestly, seeketh not her owne, is not
provoked to anger, thinketh not c
vill, revioiceth not in iniduitie, but re
joyceth in the trueth, suffereth all
thinges, beleeveth all thinges, hopeth
all things, endureth all things. And a
gaine, the same Apostle in his Epistle
to the Bomanes sayeth: Love striueth
to goe before in giving honour to o
ther, love distributeth to the saintes

ent till his returne, and giveth it to the Inkeeper. And not being there withall content, he giveth to his host an especiall charege of the ficke man: and also bindeth himelfe for him, say ing: whatsoever more than this, thou shalt laye out about thinges necessarie for his recoverie, thou shalt not loose one mite: for at my returne, I will paie thee all againe to the uttermost farthing. So then he promiseth to re turne, and therwithall declareth, that he shall not be quiet, untill he see him thorowly healed of all his woundes. Pe have here (dearely beloved) in this the Lordes Parable, a most godlie and absolute example of love. For the Samaritane doth liberallie, and wil lingly employ his whole seruice upon his needie neighbours necessitie: Te therefore owe our selves wholy and all that we have, to our neighbours behoofe, which if we bestowe on him, then doe we fulsill the dueties of love and civill humanitie. To this we will yet adde some te stimonies of the Scripture, that ther by wee may more fully understande the verie innermost pith of love, if yet peradventure anie thing may seeme to be wanting in that, which hitherto I have alleadged. Paule therefore wri ting to the Corinthians, saith: Love suffereth wrong and is courteous, love envieth not, love doth not froward ly, love swelleth not, dealeth not dis honestly, seeketh not her owne, is not provoked to anger, thinketh not c vill, revioiceth not in iniduitie, but re joyceth in the trueth, suffereth all thinges, beleeveth all thinges, hopeth all things, endureth all things. And a gaine, the same Apostle in his Epistle to the Bomanes sayeth: Love striueth to goe before in giving honour to o ther, love distributeth to the saintes
necessitie, is given to hospitalitie,
speaketh well of her persecutors, and
curseth not them that persecute her
love reioyceth with them that doe re
ioyce and weepeth with them that
weepe, and applieth it selfe to the
weaker fortes infirmitie. And againer
Gwe nothing to anie man, but to love
one an other. For hee that loveth an
other, hath fulsilled the lawe. For
this, Thou shalt not commit adulterie,
Thou shalt not steale, Thou shalt
not kill, Thou shalt not beare false
witnesse, Thou shall not lust: and if
there be anie other commaundement,
it is comprehended briefely in this
saying: namely, Thou shalt love thy
neighbour as thy selfe, Love wor
keth no ill to his neighbour, therefore
the fulfilling of the law is love or cha
ritie.
Hitherto also pertaineth the works
of mercie, which as they flow out of
love, so are they rehearsed of the Lord
in the Gospell after Matthewe, and
are especially these that followe, To
feede the hungry, To give drinke to
the thirstie, To harbour the harbour
lesse and straungers, To cover or
clothe the naked, To visite the ficke,
and to see and comfort imprisoned cap
tives. Hereunto Lactantius Li8. husti
rat. 6. cap. 12. hath an eye where hee
saith: The chiefest vertue is to keepe
hospitalitie, and to feede the poore:
To redeeme captives also, is a great
and encellent worke of righteousnesses
And as great a worke of Justice is it, to
save and defend the fatherlesse and wi
dowes, the desolate et helples, which
the lawe of God doeth everie where
command. It is also a part of the chic
fest humanitie, and a great good deede
to take in hande to heale and cherish
the sicke, that have no bodie to helpe
them Finally, that last and greatest

necessitie, is given to hospitalitie, speaketh well of her persecutors, and curseth not them that persecute her love reioyceth with them that doe re ioyce and weepeth with them that weepe, and applieth it selfe to the weaker fortes infirmitie. And againer Gwe nothing to anie man, but to love one an other. For hee that loveth an other, hath fulsilled the lawe. For this, Thou shalt not commit adulterie, Thou shalt not steale, Thou shalt not kill, Thou shalt not beare false witnesse, Thou shall not lust: and if there be anie other commaundement, it is comprehended briefely in this saying: namely, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thy selfe, Love wor keth no ill to his neighbour, therefore the fulfilling of the law is love or cha ritie. Hitherto also pertaineth the works of mercie, which as they flow out of love, so are they rehearsed of the Lord in the Gospell after Matthewe, and are especially these that followe, To feede the hungry, To give drinke to the thirstie, To harbour the harbour lesse and straungers, To cover or clothe the naked, To visite the ficke, and to see and comfort imprisoned cap tives. Hereunto Lactantius Li8. husti rat. 6. cap. 12. hath an eye where hee saith: The chiefest vertue is to keepe hospitalitie, and to feede the poore: To redeeme captives also, is a great and encellent worke of righteousnesses And as great a worke of Justice is it, to save and defend the fatherlesse and wi dowes, the desolate et helples, which the lawe of God doeth everie where command. It is also a part of the chic fest humanitie, and a great good deede to take in hande to heale and cherish the sicke, that have no bodie to helpe them Finally, that last and greatest
